posts.name: Graham Denney
posts.cooked: So my team is making a deep climb, we are using 2 neo vortex each on a 225:1 gear ratio (yes we know thatâ€™s too high of a ratio). But my team is currently a little stuck with what we should do to keep the robot hanging after the match ends and to stay in the air for the 3 seconds. We donâ€™t quite know if this is a mechanical or a coding problem, any help would be greatly appreciated. I donâ€™t know the bots weight at the moment since it isnâ€™t complete, so assume its max weight

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Are your motors set to brake mode?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
(Edit: after you check brake mode as mentioned above)

Some of this depends on the mechanical design of the climber, (e.g. how much mechanical advantage does the cage have against the motors)

If you could share a picture, sketch, or something along those lines (even a detailed description with some rough measurements) we may be able to help better

posts.name: Graham Denney
posts.cooked: we havent really started testing full time yet, this is more of a question because i am looking forward

posts.name: Graham Denney
posts.cooked: I can definetly do those later tonight at my teams meeting, but its also very similar to Penn states RI3D bot

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: 2 motors on 225:1 with braking mode should do itâ€¦ but if not, Iâ€™d look into ratchets. We picked up 2 Sport Ratchet kits this year, and theyâ€™re awesome. A few years ago, we even put a 1/2" socket on a ratchet, constrained the handle, and put it on the output shaft of our climber. This was a one-shot climb, whereas the Sport allows adjustments using a servo to unlock it. Iâ€™m not sure of the best way to implement this idea with the REV ecosystem

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: I believe that ours has 2x Neos on 250:1 gearing with brake mode enabled. We donâ€™t have any issues hanging for the required time, and itâ€™s also super fast.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked: Our climber is using a single standard Neo with I think a 125:1 gear box controller set to brake mode and has no problem staying up for the required time. When fully retracted the cage is sitting at about an 80 degree angle with the pivot point on the bottom 1/4 of the cage.

posts.name: David Berry
posts.cooked: Weâ€™re on a 625:1 and had the most consistent climb at our comp till we blew up 2 of the planetaries in the finals

posts.name: Matt Boehm
posts.cooked: Sometimes a mechanical spring loaded hook can do it or something like a gate latch

posts.name: Lotem
posts.cooked: @Eliot designed a ratchet for a max planetary system or you can use this servo actuated ratchet system for Andymark sport gearboxes, we ran a 225 ratio at northern lights and are switching to Eliotâ€™s design for Midwest.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Even simpler: zip tie a ratchet wrench to a hex shaft in the gearbox.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked: Edit our climber gearbox is a 48:1 reduction using a single Neo. We hold after the climb just fine.

First of course check that youâ€™re in break mode and if that keeps it up.

Then if that doesnâ€™t work, Iâ€™d prioritize ratchets over latches as they will be generally easier for you to design and deal with:

If you can make the full climb actuation only go in one direction and it has a 1/2" hex shaft somewhere â†’ 1/2" wrench ratchet (double up if needed)

If using a planetary gearbox â†’ you can try the options mentioned above from AndyMark or Eliot

If using pneumatics already for other things â†’ pancake cylinder brake (will need photos to indicate where to add it)

Otherwise â†’ spring latch (will need photos to provide a good recommendation)
225:1 is a ridiculous gear ratio. It should have absolutely no issues holding the robot up in brake mode. As others have said, check that first.
